canonical_explanation.text: Two triangles are congruent if they are identical in shape and size. The five congruence rules are SAS (Side-Angle-Side), ASA (Angle-Side-Angle), AAS (Angle-Angle-Side), SSS (Side-Side-Side), and RHS (Right angle-Hypotenuse-Side). In an isosceles triangle, angles opposite to equal sides are equal, and vice versa. The triangle inequality theorem states that the sum of any two sides is greater than the third side, and the side opposite the larger angle is longer.
rules: SAS: Two triangles are congruent if two sides and the included angle of one equal those of the other
ASA: Two triangles are congruent if two angles and the included side of one equal those of the other
AAS: Two triangles are congruent if two angles and a non-included side of one equal those of the other
SSS: Two triangles are congruent if all three sides of one equal the corresponding sides of the other
RHS: Two right triangles are congruent if the hypotenuse and one side of one equal those of the other
In an isosceles triangle, angles opposite equal sides are equal
The side opposite the larger angle is longer
Triangle inequality: sum of any two sides > third side

questions.question_text: Two triangles are congruent if they have the same:
questions.explanation_correct: Congruent triangles are identical in both shape and size. All corresponding sides and angles are equal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Congruence means the triangles are exactly the same in shape and size, not just one property.

questions.question_text: In which congruence rule must the angle be between the two given sides?
questions.explanation_correct: In SAS (Side-Angle-Side), the angle must be the included angle between the two sides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: SAS requires the angle to be between (included by) the two sides. In ASA, the side is between the two angles.

questions.question_text: SSA (Side-Side-Angle) is a valid congruence criterion.
questions.explanation_correct: SSA is not a valid congruence criterion because two different triangles can have the same two sides and a non-included angle (the ambiguous case).
questions.explanation_incorrect: SSA can lead to two possible triangles (ambiguous case), so it is not a valid congruence rule.

questions.question_text: If triangle ABC ≅ triangle DEF, then which side corresponds to AB?
questions.explanation_correct: In the notation ABC ≅ DEF, corresponding vertices are A↔D, B↔E, C↔F. So AB corresponds to DE.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The order of letters determines correspondence. A↔D, B↔E, C↔F, so side AB = side DE.

questions.question_text: RHS congruence rule applies to which type of triangles?
questions.explanation_correct: RHS (Right angle-Hypotenuse-Side) congruence is specifically for right-angled triangles only.
questions.explanation_incorrect: RHS stands for Right angle-Hypotenuse-Side and requires the triangles to be right-angled.

questions.question_text: In an isosceles triangle ABC where AB = AC, which angles are equal?
questions.explanation_correct: In triangle ABC with AB = AC, the angles opposite to equal sides are equal. Angle B (opposite AC) = Angle C (opposite AB).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angles opposite to equal sides are equal. AB = AC, so angle B (opposite AC) = angle C (opposite AB).

questions.question_text: In an equilateral triangle, all three angles are 60° each.
questions.explanation_correct: All sides are equal, so all angles are equal. Since their sum is 180°, each angle = 60°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal sides → equal angles. Three equal angles summing to 180° must each be 60°.

questions.question_text: Which of the following sets of lengths can form a triangle?
questions.explanation_correct: Triangle inequality: sum of any two sides > third side. For 5,6,10: 5+6=11>10, 5+10=15>6, 6+10=16>5. All satisfied.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Check each: 1+2=3 (not > 3), 3+4=7 (not > 8), 2+3=5 (not > 6). Only 5,6,10 satisfies the triangle inequality.

questions.question_text: In any triangle, the sum of any two sides is always ___ than the third side.
questions.explanation_correct: The triangle inequality theorem states that the sum of any two sides of a triangle is always greater than the third side.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is the triangle inequality: a + b > c, b + c > a, a + c > b for any triangle with sides a, b, c.

questions.question_text: How many congruence criteria are there for triangles?
questions.explanation_correct: There are 5 congruence criteria: SAS, ASA, AAS, SSS, and RHS.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The five criteria are SAS, ASA, AAS, SSS, and RHS.

questions.question_text: In a triangle, the side opposite to the largest angle is the:
questions.explanation_correct: In a triangle, the side opposite to the largest angle is the longest side. This is the angle-side inequality.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Larger angle → longer opposite side. The longest side is always opposite the largest angle.

questions.question_text: If in a triangle, two angles are equal, the triangle is:
questions.explanation_correct: If two angles are equal, the sides opposite to them are equal (converse of isosceles triangle theorem). So the triangle is isosceles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal angles imply equal opposite sides. Two equal sides make the triangle isosceles.

questions.question_text: If all three sides of one triangle are equal to the corresponding three sides of another triangle, the triangles are congruent by the ___ criterion.
questions.explanation_correct: When all three pairs of corresponding sides are equal, the triangles are congruent by the SSS (Side-Side-Side) criterion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: SSS stands for Side-Side-Side. Three equal pairs of sides guarantee congruence.

questions.question_text: AAA (Angle-Angle-Angle) is a valid congruence criterion for triangles.
questions.explanation_correct: AAA only proves similarity, not congruence. Two triangles with equal angles can have different sizes (e.g., one could be an enlargement of the other).
questions.explanation_incorrect: AAA guarantees the same shape but not the same size. The triangles are similar but not necessarily congruent.

questions.question_text: In triangle ABC, AB = AC = 5 cm and BC = 6 cm. What type of triangle is this?
questions.explanation_correct: Two sides are equal (AB = AC = 5 cm), so it is an isosceles triangle. It is not equilateral since BC = 6 cm ≠ 5 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: AB = AC but BC is different, so the triangle has exactly two equal sides. This is isosceles.

questions.question_text: In triangles PQR and XYZ: PQ = XY, QR = YZ, angle Q = angle Y. The triangles are congruent by:
questions.explanation_correct: Two sides (PQ=XY, QR=YZ) and the included angle (angle Q = angle Y) are equal. This is the SAS criterion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The angle Q is between sides PQ and QR. The matching angle Y is between XY and YZ. This is SAS (included angle).

questions.question_text: In triangles ABC and DEF: angle A = angle D = 90°, AB = DE = 3 cm, BC = EF = 5 cm. The triangles are congruent by:
questions.explanation_correct: Both triangles are right-angled (angle A = angle D = 90°), have equal hypotenuse (BC = EF = 5 cm), and one equal side (AB = DE = 3 cm). This is RHS.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Right angle + equal hypotenuse + equal side = RHS congruence criterion.

questions.question_text: In an isosceles triangle, the base angles are each 70°. What is the apex angle?
questions.explanation_correct: Sum of angles = 180°. Apex angle = 180° − 70° − 70° = 40°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The two base angles are 70° each. Apex = 180° − 140° = 40°.

questions.question_text: Can a triangle have sides 7 cm, 3 cm, and 2 cm?

options.text: No, because the sides are too different
Yes, it is a right triangle

questions.explanation_correct: Triangle inequality: sum of any two sides must be greater than the third. 3 + 2 = 5 < 7. This violates the inequality, so no such triangle exists.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 3 + 2 = 5, which is not greater than 7. The triangle inequality is violated.

questions.question_text: In triangles ABC and PQR: angle B = angle Q, angle C = angle R, and BC = QR. The congruence criterion used is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Two angles (B=Q, C=R) and the included side (BC=QR, which is between angles B and C) are equal. This is ASA.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The side BC is between angles B and C. With two angles and the included side equal, this is ASA.

questions.question_text: In triangle PQR, PQ = PR. If angle Q = 50°, find angle P:
questions.explanation_correct: PQ = PR, so angle Q = angle R = 50°. Angle P = 180° − 50° − 50° = 80°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal sides → equal base angles. Angle R = 50°. Angle P = 180° − 100° = 80°.

questions.question_text: In triangle ABC, angle A > angle B > angle C. Which is the longest side?
questions.explanation_correct: The side opposite the largest angle is the longest. Angle A is largest, and the side opposite A is BC. So BC is the longest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Larger angle → longer opposite side. Angle A is the largest, so BC (opposite A) is the longest side.

questions.question_text: Triangle ABC has AB = 4 cm, BC = 5 cm, AC = 6 cm. Triangle PQR has PQ = 4 cm, QR = 5 cm, PR = 6 cm. The triangles are congruent by:
questions.explanation_correct: All three pairs of corresponding sides are equal: AB=PQ=4, BC=QR=5, AC=PR=6. This is SSS congruence.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Three pairs of equal sides: SSS criterion. No angle information is needed.

questions.question_text: If the angles of a triangle are 40°, 60°, and 80°, the side opposite 80° is the longest.
questions.explanation_correct: The side opposite the largest angle (80°) is the longest side. This follows from the angle-side relationship in triangles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In any triangle, the largest angle is opposite the longest side. 80° is the largest angle.

questions.question_text: If two sides of a triangle are 5 cm and 8 cm, the third side must be:
questions.explanation_correct: By triangle inequality: |8−5| < third side < 8+5, so 3 < third side < 13 (strictly).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The third side must be greater than |8−5| = 3 and less than 8+5 = 13. Endpoints are excluded.

questions.question_text: ABCD is a square. Diagonal AC divides it into triangles ABC and ACD. These triangles are congruent by:
questions.explanation_correct: In a square: all sides equal, all angles 90°, diagonals equal. ABC ≅ ACD by SSS (three sides equal), SAS (two sides and included angle), and RHS (right angle, hypotenuse AC, and equal sides).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The two triangles formed by a diagonal of a square can be proven congruent by SSS, SAS, and RHS — all apply.

questions.question_text: In an isosceles triangle with vertex angle 40°, each base angle is ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: The two base angles are equal. Each = (180° − 40°)/2 = 140°/2 = 70°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Base angles = (180° − vertex angle)/2 = (180° − 40°)/2 = 70°.

questions.question_text: In triangles ABC and DEF: angle A = angle D, angle B = angle E, AB = DE. Which congruence rule applies?

options.text: B or C depending on which side AB is

questions.explanation_correct: If AB is the side between angles A and B, it's ASA. If AB is not between the two given angles, it's AAS. Both are valid criteria.
questions.explanation_incorrect: AB is between angles A and B, so this is ASA. But since angle C = angle F follows from the other two angles, AAS could also apply.

questions.question_text: In triangle ABC, BC = 6 cm, AB = 4 cm. Which of the following can be the length of AC?
questions.explanation_correct: Third side must satisfy |6−4| < AC < 6+4, i.e., 2 < AC < 10. Only 5 cm falls in this range.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By triangle inequality: 2 < AC < 10. 1 and 2 are too small (≤ 2), 11 is too large (≥ 10). Only 5 works.

questions.question_text: The perpendicular from the vertex angle to the base of an isosceles triangle bisects the base.
questions.explanation_correct: In an isosceles triangle, the perpendicular from the apex to the base bisects the base and also bisects the vertex angle. This follows from the congruence of the two resulting triangles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The altitude from the vertex of an isosceles triangle to the base creates two congruent right triangles (by RHS), proving the base is bisected.

questions.question_text: In quadrilateral ABCD, AB = AD and BC = DC. If AC is a diagonal, which congruence rule proves triangle ABC ≅ triangle ADC?
questions.explanation_correct: AB=AD, BC=DC, and AC=AC (common side). All three pairs of sides are equal, so SSS criterion applies.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Three pairs of equal sides: AB=AD, BC=DC, AC=AC (common). This is SSS congruence.

questions.question_text: ABC is an isosceles triangle with AB = AC. The bisector of angle A meets BC at D. Then:

options.text: BD = DC but AD is not perpendicular to BC

questions.explanation_correct: In isosceles triangle ABC (AB=AC), the angle bisector from A is also the median and altitude. So BD=DC and AD⊥BC.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In an isosceles triangle, the angle bisector, median, and altitude from the vertex angle all coincide.

questions.question_text: In triangle ABC, angle B = 30° and angle C = 60°. Arrange the sides in ascending order:
questions.explanation_correct: Angle A = 180°−30°−60° = 90°. Smallest angle is B=30°, so the opposite side AC is the shortest. Middle angle is C=60°, so AB is middle. Largest angle is A=90°, so BC is the longest. Ascending: AC < AB < BC.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Smaller angle → shorter opposite side. Angles in ascending order: 30° (B), 60° (C), 90° (A). Sides opposite: AC, AB, BC. So AC < AB < BC.

questions.question_text: In the figure, AB = FE, BC = ED, and angle B = angle E = 90°. Then triangle ABC ≅ triangle FED by:
questions.explanation_correct: We have two sides and the included right angle. This satisfies SAS (two sides and included angle). Also, since the triangles are right-angled with hypotenuses AC and FD, and one pair of sides equal, RHS applies too.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The right angle is included between the given sides, so SAS works. Since the triangles are right-angled, RHS also applies.

questions.question_text: In an isosceles triangle ABC with AB = AC, if angle B = 55°, then angle A = ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: AB = AC so angle B = angle C = 55°. Angle A = 180° − 55° − 55° = 70°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Base angles are equal: angle C = 55°. Angle A = 180° − 110° = 70°.

questions.question_text: In triangle ABC, AB = 8 cm, BC = 6 cm, CA = 4 cm. Which angle is the largest?
questions.explanation_correct: The longest side is AB = 8 cm. The angle opposite to AB is angle C. So angle C is the largest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Longest side → largest opposite angle. AB = 8 cm is the longest, so angle C (opposite AB) is the largest.

questions.question_text: In triangle ABC, M is the midpoint of BC. AM is the median. If AB = AC, then triangle ABM ≅ triangle ACM by:
questions.explanation_correct: AB=AC (given), BM=MC (M is midpoint), AM=AM (common). SSS applies. Also SAS (AB=AC, angle BAM=angle CAM, AM=AM). Since AM⊥BC in isosceles triangle, RHS also applies.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In an isosceles triangle, the median from the vertex is also the altitude and angle bisector. All three congruence rules apply.

questions.question_text: In triangle ABC, if angle A = angle B = angle C, find each angle:
questions.explanation_correct: All three angles are equal and sum to 180°. Each = 180°/3 = 60°. This is an equilateral triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Three equal angles: 3x = 180° → x = 60°.

questions.question_text: The difference of any two sides of a triangle is less than the third side.
questions.explanation_correct: From the triangle inequality a + b > c, we get a > c − b, i.e., c − b < a. Similarly for all combinations. So the difference of any two sides is less than the third.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This follows directly from the triangle inequality: if a + b > c, then |a − b| < c.

questions.question_text: If triangle ABC ≅ triangle QRP, then which of the following is correct?

options.text: AB = QR, BC = RP, CA = PQ
AB = QP, BC = PR, CA = RQ
AB = RP, BC = PQ, CA = QR
AB = PQ, BC = QR, CA = RP

questions.explanation_correct: ABC ≅ QRP: A↔Q, B↔R, C↔P. So AB=QR, BC=RP, CA=PQ.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Match vertices in order: A→Q, B→R, C→P. Therefore AB=QR, BC=RP, CA=PQ.

questions.question_text: In an isosceles right triangle, the angles are:
questions.explanation_correct: Isosceles + right-angled: one angle is 90°, the other two are equal. Each = (180°−90°)/2 = 45°. Angles: 45°, 45°, 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Right angle = 90°. The remaining 90° is split equally between two equal base angles: 45° each.

questions.question_text: The perimeter of a triangle with sides a, b, c is 20 cm and a = 8 cm, b = 7 cm. The third side c = ___ cm.
questions.explanation_correct: Perimeter = a + b + c = 20. So c = 20 − 8 − 7 = 5 cm. Check triangle inequality: 8+7>5, 8+5>7, 7+5>8. All satisfied.

questions.question_text: AB is a line segment and C is a point such that AC = BC. If D and E are points on AB such that AD = BE, then triangle ACD ≅ triangle BCE by:
questions.explanation_correct: AC=BC (given), AD=BE (given). Angle A = Angle B (base angles of isosceles triangle ACB). So by SAS: AC=BC, angle A=angle B, AD=BE.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In isosceles triangle ACB, angle A = angle B. With AC=BC and AD=BE, SAS congruence applies.

questions.question_text: In a triangle, the angle opposite to the longest side is always:
questions.explanation_correct: The angle opposite to the longest side is always the largest angle in the triangle. It could be acute, right, or obtuse.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Longer side → larger opposite angle. The longest side always has the largest opposite angle.

questions.question_text: In triangle PQR, PQ > PR > QR. Which is the smallest angle?
questions.explanation_correct: The smallest side QR is opposite angle P. So angle P is the smallest angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Shortest side → smallest opposite angle. QR is shortest, and the angle opposite QR is angle P.

questions.question_text: If two triangles have equal areas, they must be congruent.
questions.explanation_correct: Equal areas do not imply congruence. For example, a 3-4-5 right triangle and a triangle with base 6 and height 2 both have area 6, but are not congruent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Area equality does not guarantee congruence. Many differently shaped triangles can have the same area.

questions.question_text: In an isosceles triangle ABC with AB = AC, angle A = 100°. Find angle B:
questions.explanation_correct: AB = AC, so angle B = angle C. Angle B = (180° − 100°)/2 = 80°/2 = 40°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Base angles: (180° − 100°)/2 = 40° each.

questions.question_text: AD is the altitude from A to BC in triangle ABC. If AB = AC, then by which congruence rule is triangle ABD ≅ triangle ACD?
questions.explanation_correct: Both triangles are right-angled at D (AD is altitude). AB = AC (hypotenuse), AD = AD (common side). By RHS, triangle ABD ≅ triangle ACD.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Right angle at D, equal hypotenuses AB = AC, common side AD. This is RHS congruence.

questions.question_text: The lengths 4 cm, 4 cm, and 8 cm can form a triangle.
questions.explanation_correct: The triangle inequality requires the sum of any two sides to be strictly greater than the third. 4 + 4 = 8 = 8, which is not greater. So no triangle can be formed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 4 + 4 = 8, which equals (not exceeds) the third side. The strict inequality is violated.

questions.question_text: In triangle ABC ≅ triangle DEF, if angle A = 50° and angle E = 60°, then angle C = ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: Since ABC ≅ DEF: angle A = angle D = 50°, angle B = angle E = 60°. Angle C = 180° − 50° − 60° = 70°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Corresponding angles: A=D=50°, B=E=60°. Angle C = 180° − 50° − 60° = 70°.
